revision.comment: Fixing style/layout errors and removed underlinked template
revision.text:
{{prose|date=May 2017}} The term "biological computation" refers, variously, to any of the following:
- the study of the [[computation]]s performed by natural [[biota (ecology)|biota]],<ref>Mitchell, M. (2010) Biological Computation. http://www.santafe.edu/media/workingpapers/10-09-021.pdf</ref><ref>Didales, K. (2007) ''Being - Our New Understanding of the Meaning of Life.'' https://sites.google.com/site/djhbrown2/IPM.pdf</ref><ref>Bray, D. ''Wetware: A Computer in Every Living Cell'' (2009) {{ISBN|0-300-14173-4}}, {{ISBN|978-0-300-14173-3}} </ref><ref>NIMBios (2015) ''Information and entropy in biological systems ''http://www.nimbios.org/workshops/WS_entropy</ref> including the subject matter of [[systems biology]].
- the design of [[algorithm]]s inspired by the computational methods of biota <ref>Lamm, E. and Unger, R. ''Biological Computation''. Chapman and Hall/CRC, 2011.</ref>
- the [[design]] and [[engineering]] of manufactured computational devices using [[synthetic biology]] components<ref>Biological Computation Group at MIT - Psrg.csail.mit.edu {{cite web|url=http://www.psrg.csail.mit.edu/biocomp |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2013-10-23 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20131030232132/http://www.psrg.csail.mit.edu/biocomp/ |archivedate=2013-10-30 |df= }}</ref><ref>Sergi Regot, Javier Macia, Núria Conde, Kentaro Furukawa, Jimmy Kjellén, Tom Peeters, Stefan Hohmann, Eulàlia de Nadal, Francesc Posas & Ricard Solé (2011) Distributed biological computation with multicellular engineered networks. http://www.nature.com/nature/journal/v469/n7329/full/nature09679.html </ref>
- computer methods for the analysis of biological data, elsewhere called [[computational biology]]<ref>Biological Computation - Microsoft Research. http://research.microsoft.com/en-us/groups/biology</ref>
When biological computation refers to using [[biology]] to build [[computer]]s, it is a subfield of [[computer science]] and is distinct from the [[interdisciplinary]] [[science]] of [[bioinformatics]] which simply uses computers to better understand biology.
==Books== *''Biological computation'' (2011) by Ehud Lamm and Ron Unger, CRC Press, {{ISBN|978-1-4200-8796-3}}.
==References== {{Reflist}} {{Comp-sci-stub}} [[Category:Computational biology]] [[Category:Computational fields of study]]

[[File:Carnac megalith alignment 1.jpg|thumb|The ''Ménec'' alignments, the most well-known megalithic site among the Carnac stones]] [[File:Alignement Kerlescan Carnac.jpg|thumb|Stones in the ''Kerlescan'' alignments]] The '''Carnac stones''' ([[Breton language|Breton]]: ''Steudadoù Karnag'') are an exceptionally dense collection of [[megalith]]ic sites around the village of [[Carnac]] in [[Brittany]], consisting of [[stone row|alignments]], [[dolmen]]s, [[tumulus|tumuli]] and single [[menhir]]s. More than 3,000 [[prehistoric]] [[standing stone]]s were hewn from local [[Rock (geology)|rock]] and erected by the pre-[[Celts|Celtic]] people of [[Brittany]], and form the largest such collection in the world.<ref name="Menhir">{{cite web |url=http://menhirs.tripod.com/intro.html |title=Megaliths of Carnac: Introduction |publisher=menhirs.tripod.com |accessdate=2010-01-07 }}</ref> Most of the stones are within the Breton village of [[Carnac]], but some to the east are within [[La Trinité-sur-Mer]]. The stones were erected at some stage during the [[Neolithic]] period, probably around [[33rd century BCE|3300 BCE]], but some may date to as early as 4500 BCE.<ref>{{cite web| url=http://www.sacred-destinations.com/france/carnac-stones.htm| title=Carnac Stones, Brittany| publisher=Sacred Destinations Travel Guide| accessdate=2006-05-17}}</ref>
Although the stones date from 4500 BCE, modern myths were formed which resulted from 1st century AD [[Roman Gaul|Roman]] and later Christian occupations. A Christian myth associated with the stones held that they were pagan soldiers in pursuit of [[Pope Cornelius]] when he turned them to stone.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://news.therecord.com/Life/Travel/article/320293 |title=TheRecord.com - Travel - Marvelling at Carnac's stones |publisher=News.therecord.com |date=2008-03-08 |accessdate=2009-05-05}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.franceholidays.co.uk/france_holidays/brittany.php |title=France Holidays, Brittany |publisher=Franceholidays.co.uk |date= |accessdate=2009-05-05}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.bigsiteofamazingfacts.com/why-are-carnac-stones-called-megaliths |title=Why are Carnac Stones Called Megaliths? |publisher=Big Site of Amazing Facts |accessdate=2010-01-07 }}</ref> Brittany has its own local versions of the [[King Arthur|Arthurian]] cycle. Local tradition claims that the reason they stand in such perfectly straight lines is that they are a [[Roman legion]] turned to stone by [[Merlin]].{{Citation needed|date=August 2018}}
In recent centuries, many of the sites have been neglected, with reports of [[dolmen]]s being used as sheep shelters, chicken sheds or even ovens.<ref name="megalithic 9178">{{cite web| url=http://www.megalithic.co.uk/article.php?sid=9178| publisher=The Megalithic Portal and Megalith Map| title=La Madeleine dolmen Burial Chamber (Dolmen)| author=TheCaptain| date=3 January 2005| accessdate=2006-05-17| deadurl=yes| archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/66aduXnp6?url=http://www.megalithic.co.uk/article.php?sid=9178| archivedate=1 April 2012| df=}}</ref> Even more commonly, stones have been removed to make way for roads, or as [[building material]]s. The continuing management of the sites remains a controversial topic.<ref name="Menhir"/><ref>{{cite web |url=http://megaliths.sherwoodonline.de/menhir.html |title=Megaliths of Carnac: Standing Stones / Menhirs |publisher=megaliths.sherwoodonline.de |accessdate=2010-01-07 }}</ref>
==Alignments== [[File:Menhirs carnac.jpg|center|795px|border|Menec alignment, at the western end]]
There are three major groups of [[stone row]]s — ''Ménec'', ''Kermario'' and ''Kerlescan'' — which may have once formed a single group, but have been split up as stones were removed for other purposes. [[File:Menec.JPG|thumb|left|Model of the ''Ménec'' alignment]]
===''Ménec'' alignments=== [[File:Alignement Menec Carnac.jpg|thumb|Stones in the ''Ménec'' alignment]] Eleven <!-- was "Twelve", my source is just the brochure from the tourist office --> converging rows of menhirs stretching for {{convert|1165|by|100|m|ft|lk=on|abbr=off}}. There are what [[Alexander Thom]] considered to be the remains of [[stone circle]]s at either end. According to the tourist office there is a "[[Stone circles|cromlech]] containing 71 stone blocks" at the western end and a very ruined cromlech at the eastern end. The largest stones, around {{convert|4|m|ft|abbr=off}} high, are at the wider, western end; the stones then become as small as {{convert|0.6|m|ftin|lk=out|abbr=off}} high along the length of the alignment before growing in height again toward the extreme eastern end.
====''Kermario'' alignment==== [[File:Kermario.JPG|thumb|left|Model of the ''Kermario'' alignment]] [[File:Kermario Carnac.JPG|thumb|Stones in the ''Kermario'' alignment]] This fan-like layout recurs a little further along to the east in the ''Kermario'' (''House of the Dead'')<ref>{{cite web| url=http://myweb.tiscali.co.uk/celynog/Brittany/mane_kermario.htm| title=Mané Kermario| accessdate=2006-05-17| deadurl=yes| archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20060923052428/http://myweb.tiscali.co.uk/celynog/Brittany/mane_kermario.htm| archivedate=2006-09-23| df=}}</ref> alignment. It consists of 1029 stones<ref>[http://www.pvf.dircon.co.uk/BCH-4B(Carnac).html Holidays in Brittany] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20051027065115/http://www.pvf.dircon.co.uk/BCH-4B%28Carnac%29.html |date=October 27, 2005 }}</ref> in ten columns, about {{convert|1300|m|ft|abbr=on}} in length.{{Citation needed|date=March 2013}} A stone circle to the east end, where the stones are shorter, was revealed by [[aerial photography]].<ref>{{cite web |url=http://myweb.tiscali.co.uk/celynog/Brittany/kermario.htm |title=Kermario |publisher=Myweb.tiscali.co.uk |date= |accessdate=2009-05-05 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20071024184337/http://myweb.tiscali.co.uk/celynog/Brittany/kermario.htm |archivedate=2007-10-24 |df= }}</ref>
====''Kerlescan'' alignments==== [[File:Kerlescan.JPG|thumb|left|Model of the ''Kerlescan'' alignment]] A smaller group of 555 stones, further to the east of the other two sites. It is composed of 13 lines with a total length of about {{convert|800|m|ft|}}, ranging in height from {{convert|80|cm|ftin|lk=on|abbr=on}} to {{convert|4|m|ft||abbr=on}}.<ref name="dino"/> At the extreme west, where the stones are tallest, there is a [[stone circle]] which has 39 stones. There may also be another stone circle to the north.{{citation needed|date=March 2013}}
====''Petit-Ménec'' alignments==== A much smaller group, further east again of Kerlescan, falling within the commune of [[La Trinité-sur-Mer]]. These are now set in woods, and most are covered with moss and ivy.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://myweb.tiscali.co.uk/celynog/Brittany/petit_menec.htm |title=Petit Ménec |publisher=Myweb.tiscali.co.uk |date= |accessdate=2009-05-05 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/66adtG0Vq?url=http://myweb.tiscali.co.uk/celynog/Brittany/petit_menec.htm |archivedate=2012-04-01 |df= }}</ref>
===Tumuli=== There are several [[tumulus|tumuli]], mounds of earth built up over a grave. In this area, they generally feature a passage leading to a central chamber which once held neolithic artefacts.
[[File:tumulus carnac.jpg|thumbnail|''Tumulus of Saint-Michel'']] ;Saint-Michel:{{Main article|Saint-Michel tumulus}}The [[tumulus]] of Saint-Michel was constructed between 5000 BC and 3400 BC. At its base it is {{convert|125|by|60|m|ft|abbr=on}}, and is {{convert|12|m|ft|abbr=on}} high. It required {{convert|35000|m3|cuyd}} of stone and earth. Its function was the same as that of the [[Egyptian pyramids|pyramids of Egypt]]: a tomb for the members of the ruling class. It contained various funerary objects, such as 15 stone chests, pottery, jewellery, most of which are currently held by the Museum of Prehistory of Carnac.<ref name="ot-carnac historie alignment">{{cite web|url=http://www.ot-carnac.fr/version_anglaise/histoire_alignement.php |title=Office de Tourisme de Carnac |publisher=Web.archive.org |date=2006-07-03 |accessdate=2009-07-25 |archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20060703063525/http://www.ot-carnac.fr/version_anglaise/histoire_alignement.php |archivedate = 2006-07-03}}</ref> It was excavated in 1862 by [[René Galles]] with a series of vertical pits, digging down {{convert|8|m|ft|abbr=on}}. Le Rouzic also excavated it between 1900 and 1907 discovering the tomb and the stone chests.<ref name="bc">{{cite web |author=Annick Jacq |url=http://www.bretagne-celtic.com/carte_carnac.htm |title=Carnac |publisher=Bretagne-celtic.com |date= |accessdate=2009-05-05 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/66adtkqCc?url=http://www.bretagne-celtic.com/carte_carnac.htm |archivedate=2012-04-01 |df= }}</ref> :A chapel was built on top in 1663 but was rebuilt in 1813, before being destroyed in 1923. The current building is an identical reconstruction of the 1663 chapel, built in 1926. <!-- according to tourist office info, the chapel was built in 1664, also refers to this extra reconstruction "vers 1813" -->
;Moustoir <small>{{coord|47.6119|N|3.0608|W|type:landmark}}</small>:<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.megalithic.co.uk/article.php?sid=9182 |title=The Megalithic Portal and Megalith Map: Moustoir tumulus Moustoir Er Mané] Chambered Tomb] |publisher=Megalithic.co.uk |date= |accessdate=2009-06-23}}</ref> Also known as ''Er Mané'', it is a [[chamber tomb]] {{convert|85|m|ft|abbr=on}} long, {{convert|35|m|ft|abbr=on}} wide, and {{convert|5|m|ft|abbr=on}} high. It has a dolmen at the west end, and two tombs at the east end.<ref name="ot-carnac historie alignment"/> A small menhir, approximately {{convert|3|m|ft|0|abbr=on}} high, is nearby. {{clear}}
===Dolmens=== [[File:Dolmen Roch-Feutet.JPG|thumb|The dolmen Er-Roc'h-Feutet. An inscription next to every standing stone formation proclaims ownership by the state of France.]]
There are several [[dolmen]]s scattered around the area. These dolmens are generally considered to have been tombs; however, the acidic soil of Brittany has eroded away the bones. They were constructed with several large stones supporting a capstone, then buried under a mound of earth. In many cases, the mound is no longer present, sometimes due to archeological excavation, and only the large stones remain, in various states of ruin. ;''Er-Roc'h-Feutet'': North, near the Chapelle de La Madeleine. Has a completely covered roof. ;''La Madeleine'' <small>{{coord|47.6208|N|3.0482|W|type:landmark}}</small>:<ref name=autogenerated1>{{cite web |url=http://www.megalithic.co.uk/article.php?sid=9178 |title=The Megalithic Portal and Megalith Map: La Madeleine (Carnac) Burial Chamber (Dolmen) |publisher=Megalithic.co.uk |date= |accessdate=2009-05-05 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/66aduXnp6?url=http://www.megalithic.co.uk/article.php?sid=9178 |archivedate=2012-04-01 |df= }}</ref> A large dolmen measuring {{convert|12|by|5|m|ft|abbr=on}}, with a {{convert|5|m|ft|abbr=on}} long broken capstone.<ref name="megalithic 9178"/> It is named after the nearby Chapelle de La Madeleine, which is still used. [[File:Tumulus de Kercado 2005 02.jpg|thumb|right|250px|'''Dolmen of Kercado'''. Though smaller than St. Michel, older by many centuries before 4800 BC]] ;''Kercado'': A rare dolmen still covered by its original [[cairn]]. South of the Kermario alignments, it is {{convert|25|to(-)|30|m|ft}} wide, {{convert|5|m|ft|abbr=on}} high, and has a small menhir on top. Previously surrounded by a circle of small menhirs {{convert|4|m|ft|abbr=on}} out,<ref name="bc"/> the main passage is {{convert|6.5|m|ft|abbr=on}} long and leads to a large chamber where numerous artifacts were found, including axes, arrowheads, some animal and human teeth, some pearls and [[sherd]]s, and 26 beads of a unique bluish [[Nephrite]] gem. It has some [[Megalithic art]] carved on its inner surfaces in the form of serpentines and a human-sized double-axe symbol carved in the underside of its main roof slab. In ancient cultures, the axe and more precisely the [[Labrys|bi-pennis]] used to represent the lightning powers of divinity. It was constructed around 4600 BC and used for approximately 3,000 years.<ref name="bc"/>
;''Mané Brizil'' ;''Kerlescan'':A roughly rectangular mound, with only one [[Caprock|capstone]] remaining. It is aligned east-to-west, with a passage entrance to the south.<ref name="tiscali kerlescan">{{cite web |url=http://myweb.tiscali.co.uk/celynog/Brittany/kerlescan.htm |title=Kerlescan |publisher=Myweb.tiscali.co.uk |date= |accessdate=2009-05-05 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/66adsjbqU?url=http://myweb.tiscali.co.uk/celynog/Brittany/kerlescan.htm |archivedate=2012-04-01 |df= }}</ref> ;''Kermarquer'': On a small hill, has two separate chambers. ;''Mané-Kerioned'' (Pixies' mound or ''Grotte de Grionnec''<ref name="bc"/>):A group of three dolmens with layout unique in Brittany,<ref name="bc"/> once covered by a tumulus. Whereas most groups of dolmens are parallel, these are arranged in a [[horseshoe]]. The largest of the three is at the east, {{convert|11|m|ft}}.<ref name="ot-carnac historie alignment"/> [[File:Crucuno dolmen.jpg|thumb|right| The Crucuno dolmen]] ;''Crucuno'':A "classic" dolmen, with a {{convert|40|tonne|short ton|lk=on|adj=on}}, {{convert|7.6|m|ftin|adj=on}} tablestone resting on pillars roughly {{convert|1.8|m|ftin|abbr=on}} high. Prior to 1900, it was connected by a passage making it {{convert|24|m|ft|abbr=on}} long.<ref name="bc"/> ;''Crucuno stone rectangle'' <small>{{coord|47.625|N|3.121667|W|type:landmark}}</small>: A classic 3, 4, 5 rectangle of 21 [[menhir]]s varying in height from {{convert|0.91|m|ft}} to {{convert|2.4|m|ft}} that is aligned along its diagonal to the midsummer sunrise. [[Alexander Thom]] suggested it measured forty by thirty of his [[megalithic yard]]s.<ref name="ThomThom1978">{{cite book|author1=Alexander Thom|author2=Archibald Stevenson Thom|title=Megalithic remains in Britain and Brittany|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=WbTeKi00QH0C|accessdate=30 April 2011|year=1978|publisher=Oxford University Press US|isbn=978-0-19-858156-7}}</ref>
===Other formations=== [[File:QuadrilatereduManio.JPG|thumb|left|The Manio quadrilateral arrangement.]] [[File:Carnac Geant du Manio.jpg|thumb|upright|The Manio "Giant".]] There are some individual menhirs and at least one other formation which do not fit into the above categories. ;''Manio'' quadrilateral: An arrangement of stones to form the perimeter of a large rectangle. Originally a "tertre tumulus" with a central mound, it is {{convert|37|m|ft|abbr=on}} long, and aligned to east of northeast. The quadrilateral is {{convert|10|m|ft|abbr=on}} wide to the east, but only {{convert|7|m|ft|abbr=on}} wide at the west.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://myweb.tiscali.co.uk/celynog/Brittany/manio_quadrilateral.htm |title=Manio Quadrilateral |publisher=Myweb.tiscali.co.uk |date= |accessdate=2009-05-05 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/66advg6GF?url=http://myweb.tiscali.co.uk/celynog/Brittany/manio_quadrilateral.htm |archivedate=2012-04-01 |df= }}</ref> ;''Manio'' giant <small>{{coord|47.6034|N|3.056|W|type:landmark}}</small>:<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.megalithic.co.uk/article.php?sid=9143 |title=The Megalithic Portal and Megalith Map: Geant du Manio Le Manio] Standing Stone (Menhir)] |publisher=Megalithic.co.uk |date= |accessdate=2009-06-23}}</ref> Near the quadrilateral is a single massive menhir, now known as the "Giant". Over {{convert|6.5|m|ft|abbr=on}} tall, it was re-erected around 1900 by Zacharie Le Rouzic,<ref name="bc"/> and overlooks the nearby Kerlescan alignment.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://myweb.tiscali.co.uk/celynog/Brittany/geant_de_manio.htm |title=Géant de Manio |publisher=Myweb.tiscali.co.uk |date= |accessdate=2009-05-05 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20071024131838/http://myweb.tiscali.co.uk/celynog/Brittany/geant_de_manio.htm |archivedate=2007-10-24 |df= }}</ref>
==Excavation and analysis== [[File:Menec Single.JPG|thumb|left|Large upright in the ''Ménec'' alignment]] From the 1720s increasing interest was shown in these features.<ref>[http://www.culture.gouv.fr/culture/arcnat/megalithes/en/mega/megacarhis_en.htm Astonishing Heaps of Stones]</ref> In 1796, for example, [[Théophile Corret de la Tour d'Auvergne|La Tour d'Auvergne]] attributed them to [[druid]]ic gatherings.<ref name="bc"/> In 1805, A. Maudet de Penhoët claimed they represented stars in the sky.<ref name="bc"/>
Englishmen [[Francis Ronalds]] and [[Alexander Blair (writer)|Alexander Blair]] made a detailed survey of the stones in 1834.<ref>{{Cite book|title=Sir Francis Ronalds: Father of the Electric Telegraph|last=Ronalds|first=B.F.|publisher=Imperial College Press|year=2016|isbn=978-1-78326-917-4|location=London|pages=}}</ref> Ronalds created the first accurate drawings of many of them with his patented [[perspective machine|perspective tracing instrument]], which were printed in a book ''Sketches at Carnac (Brittany) in 1834''.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://books.google.co.uk/books/about/Sketches_at_Carnac_Brittany_in_1834.html?id=HuA-AAAAYAAJ&redir_esc=y|title=Sketches at Carnac (Brittany) in 1834|last=Blair and Ronalds|first=|date=1836|website=Google Books|publisher=|access-date=22 June 2016}}</ref>
===Miln and Le Rouzic=== The first extensive excavation was performed in the 1860s by Scottish antiquary [[James Miln]] (1819–1881), who reported that by then fewer than 700 of the 3,000 stones were still standing.<ref name="ml">[http://www.megalithic.co.uk/article.php?sid=2146410728 The Independent: Bretons fight for Carnac to stay in the Stone Age] {{webarchive|url=https://www.webcitation.org/66adqwmsr?url=http://www.megalithic.co.uk/article.php?sid=2146410728 |date=2012-04-01 }}</ref> Towards 1875, Miln engaged a local boy, {{Interlanguage link multi|Zacharie Le Rouzic|fr}} (1864–1939), as his assistant, and Zacharie learnt archaeology on the job. After Miln's death, he left the results of his excavations to the town of Carnac, and the ''James Miln Museum'' was established there by his brother Robert to house the artifacts. Zacharie became the director of the Museum and, although self-taught, became an internationally recognised expert on megaliths in the region. He too left the results of his work to the town, and the museum is now named ''Le Musée de Préhistoire James Miln – Zacharie le Rouzic''.<ref name=megalithia>[http://www.megalithia.com/brittany/carnac/ Carnac — Megalithic alignments of standing stones.]</ref><ref name=museedecarnac>[http://www.museedecarnac.com/musee_carnac.htm Musée de Préhistoire James Miln – Zacharie le Rouzic] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20060517075032/http://www.museedecarnac.com/musee_carnac.htm |date=2006-05-17 }}</ref>
===Other theories=== [[File:Carnac Ménec alignments.jpg|thumb|right|400px|The ''Ménec'' alignments of some 1,100 stones in 11 columns.]] In 1887, H. de Cleuziou argued for a connection between the rows of stones and the directions of sunsets at the solstices.<ref name="bc"/>
Among more recent studies, [[Alexander Thom]] worked with his son Archie from 1970 to 1974 to carry out a detailed survey of the Carnac alignments, and produced a series of papers on the [[Archaeoastronomy|astronomical alignments]] of the stones as well as [[Statistics|statistical analysis]] supporting his concept of the [[Megalithic Yard|megalithic yard]].<ref name=megalithia/><ref>{{cite book | first=John Edwin | last=Wood | authorlink= | coauthors= | year=1978 | title= Sun, Moon and Standing Stones | edition=paperback 1980 | publisher=Oxford University Press | location=Oxford | isbn=0-19-285089-X }}</ref> Thom's megalithic yard has been challenged.<ref>{{cite book|last=Heggie|first=Douglas C.|title=Megalithic Science: Ancient Mathematics and Astronomy in North-west Europe|year=1981|publisher=Thames and Hudson|isbn=0-500-05036-8|page=58}}</ref><ref>{{cite book|last=Ruggles|first=Clive|title=Astronomy in Prehistoric Britain and Ireland|year=1999|publisher=Yale University Press|isbn=978-0-300-07814-5|page=83}}</ref>
There are also general theories on the use of the stones as astronomical observatories, as has been claimed for [[Stonehenge]]. According to one such theory, the [[Broken Menhir of Er Grah|massive menhir]] at nearby [[Locmariaquer]] was linked to the alignments for such a purpose.<ref name="dino">{{fr icon}} http://www.dinosoria.com/dolmen_menhir.htm</ref>
==Management== [[File:Carnac Kerlescan sheep.jpg|thumb|left|Sheep grazing around the Kerlescan alignment, part of a new management strategy.]] The ''Musée de Préhistoire James Miln – Zacharie le Rouzic'' is at the centre of conserving and displaying the artefacts from the area.<ref name=museedecarnac/> It also contains the "world's largest collection [of] prehistoric[al] exhibits"<ref name="ot-carnac historie alignment"/> with over 6,600 prehistoric objects from 136 different sites.
The monuments themselves were listed and purchased by the State at the start of the 20th century to protect them against quarrymen, and while this was successful at the time, in the middle of the century, redevelopment, changes to [[Agriculture|agricultural practices]] and increasing tourism bringing visitors to the stones led to rapid deterioration. The ''Ministère de la Culture et de la Communication'' (Heritage Ministry) re-examined the issue starting in 1984, and subsequently set up the ‘Mission Carnac’ in 1991 with the aim of rehabilitating and developing the alignments. This involved restricting [[Public-access television|public access]], launching a series of scientific and technical studies, and producing a plan for conservation and development in the area.<ref>[http://www.culture.gouv.fr/culture/arcnat/megalithes/en/rea/reacar_en.htm The Carnac Project]</ref>
As with the megalithic structure of [[Stonehenge]] in [[England]], management of the stones can be controversial. Since 1991, the main groups of stone rows have been protected from the public by fences "to help vegetation growth",<ref name="ot-carnac historie alignment"/> preventing visits except by organised tours. They are open during winter, however.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://myweb.tiscali.co.uk/celynog/Brittany/carnac.htm |title=Carnac |publisher=Myweb.tiscali.co.uk |date= |accessdate=2009-05-05 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/68HCZwQLf?url=http://myweb.tiscali.co.uk/celynog/Brittany/carnac.htm |archivedate=2012-06-08 |df= }}</ref> When [[James Miln]] studied the stones in the 1860s, he reported that fewer than 700 of the 3,000 stones were still standing, and subsequent work during the 1930s and 1980s (using bulldozers) rearranged the stones, re-erecting some, to make way for roads or other structures. In 2002, protesters invaded the site, opening the padlocks and allowing tourists free entry.<ref name="ml"/> In particular, the group ''Collectif Holl a gevred'' (French and Breton for "the everyone-together collective") occupied the visitor centre for the Kermario alignment, demanding an immediate stop to current management plans and local input into further plans.<ref>{{fr icon}} {{cite web |url=http://nopasaran.samizdat.net/article.php3?id_article=662 |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2006-05-11 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20081227231719/http://nopasaran.samizdat.net/article.php3?id_article=662 |archivedate=2008-12-27 |df= }}</ref>
In recent years, management of the site has also experimented with allowing sheep to graze among the stones, in order to keep [[gorse]] and other weeds under control.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://myweb.tiscali.co.uk/celynog/Brittany/menec_west.htm |title=Menec West |publisher=Myweb.tiscali.co.uk |date= |accessdate=2009-05-05 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/68HCaWx6P?url=http://myweb.tiscali.co.uk/celynog/Brittany/menec_west.htm |archivedate=2012-06-08 |df= }}</ref> {{clear}}
==See also== *[[Prehistory of Brittany]] *[[Standing stone]]s *[[Dolmen]] *[[Tumulus]] *[[Passage grave]] *[[Stone row]] *[[Megalith]] *[[List of megalithic sites]]
==References==
===Bibliography=== *''A Guide to the Stone Circles of Britain, Ireland and Brittany'' Aubrey Burl, Yale University Press 1995, {{ISBN|0-300-06331-8}} * ''Carnac: Guide pratique 2006'' (provided by Carnac tourist office) * ''"The megaliths of Brittany"'' <small>by [[Jacques Briard]], translated by [[Juan-Paolo Perre]], [[copyright|©]] 1997-2007, Éditions Gisserot</small> *''From Carnac to Callanish: the prehistoric stone rows and avenues of Britain, Ireland and Brittany'' [[Aubrey Burl]], [[Yale University Press]], {{ISBN|0-300-05575-7}}, 1993 *{{cite web |url=http://www.megalithia.com/bibliographyuk.html#carn2call |title=Standing Stones - M E g A L i T h i A - Books about megalithic sites (UK version) |publisher=M E g A L i T h i A |date=2005-07-17 |accessdate=2009-07-25}} *{{cite book|last=Mason|first=Paul|authorlink=Paul Mason (author)|title=The Mystery of Stone Circles|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=uCvibkN1SC0C|accessdate=25 February 2010|date=15 March 2008|publisher=Heinemann-Raintree|isbn=978-1-4329-1023-5|ref=Mason69}}

===Online maps=== *http://members.tripod.com/Menhirs/dolmen.html  — main sites in the Morbihan area *https://www.webcitation.org/66adtkqCc?url=http://www.bretagne-celtic.com/carte_carnac.htm  — historical map *http://www.megalithia.com/brittany/carnac/  — basic arrangement of the main alignments

{{For|Center for Security Studies at Georgetown University|School of Foreign Service}} {{Refimprove|date=December 2016}} {{onesource|date= February 2017}} {{Infobox Organization |name = Center for Security Studies |image = |image_border = |size = |caption = |abbreviation = CSS |msize = |mcaption = |motto = |formation = 1986 |type = |headquarters = |location = [[Zurich]], [[Switzerland]] |membership = |leader_title = |leader_name = |key_people = |num_staff = |website = {{URL|http://www.css.ethz.ch/en/|Official website}} }}
The '''Center for Security Studies''' ('''CSS''') is a center at the [[Swiss Federal Institute of Technology in Zurich]], which focuses on Swiss and international security.<ref name=AboutUs>{{cite web|url=http://www.css.ethz.ch/en/center.html |title=About Us |website= css.ethz.ch| publisher= Center for Security Studies, Dept. of Humanities, Social and Political Sciences, ETH Zurich (Swiss Federal Institute of Technology in Zurich) |date= |accessdate=2017-03-27}}</ref><ref name=OSCENetwork>{{cite web|url=http://osce-network.net/members/institutions/center-for-security-studies-css-eth-zuerich/ |title=OSCE Network |website=osce-network.net| publisher= OSCE Network, OSCE Network of Think Tanks and Academic Institutions |date= |accessdate=2017-03-27}}</ref>
==Overview== The center was founded by Prof. Dr. Kurt Spillmann in 1986 and has been led by Prof. Dr. Andreas Wenger since 2002. It also constitutes as part of the [[Center for Comparative and International Studies]] (CIS) along with the political science professorships at the Swiss Federal Institute of Technology in Zurich and the [[University of Zurich]].<ref name=AboutUs />
The mission of the CSS is to examine the challenges surrounding security policy development and how to deal with them. It does this by performing research on security-related issues and by training researchers and practitioners. The center also includes an independent think tank, which focuses on Swiss and international security policy as well as furthering peace. Another key aim of the CSS is to serve as a link between academia, practitioners and the public on security matters.<ref>{{cite web| url= http://www.css.ethz.ch/en/center/mission-statement.html |title=Mission Statement |publisher= Center for Security Studies, Dept. of Humanities, Social and Political Sciences, ETH Zurich (Swiss Federal Institute of Technology in Zurich) |website= css.ethz.ch |date= |accessdate=2016-12-20}}</ref>
==Projects== Projects which have been supported by the CSS include the [[Parallel History Project]],<ref>{{cite web| url= http://www.php.isn.ethz.ch/lory1.ethz.ch/about/imprint/index.html |title=Imprint − Parallel History Project |website= ethz.ch |date= | publisher= Center for Security Studies, Dept. of Humanities, Social and Political Sciences, ETH Zurich (Swiss Federal Institute of Technology in Zurich)| accessdate= 2017-01-07}}</ref> an online project which collected together and analyzed declassified and other government documents relating to the [[Cold War]], as well as the [[International Relations and Security Network]], an online information service that provided a range of open access products and resources on [[international relations]]. While the International Relations and Security Network was closed in 2016, its extensive [[digital library]] as well as other products have been integrated into the CSS and transformed into a new project, CSS Resources.<ref>{{cite web| url= http://www.css.ethz.ch/en/services.html |title=Resources | publisher= Center for Security Studies, Dept. of Humanities, Social and Political Sciences, ETH Zurich (Swiss Federal Institute of Technology in Zurich)|website= css.ethz.ch |date= 2016-10-10 |accessdate=2016-12-20}}</ref>
==References== {{Reflist}}
==External links== * [http://www.css.ethz.ch/index_EN Center for Security Studies (CSS)]. (official website)
